section.title: The Force of Interest as an Instantaneous Approximation
section.p: Recall that given an accumulation function A(t), the force of interest at time t is defined as \delta_t = \frac{d}{dt} \ln(A(t))
In this section, we will see where that definition comes from, and why this captures an instantaneous percentage change.

introduction.p: As a preliminary step, we need a formula for the base b of an exponential function of the form y=a\cdot b^x given that the graph passes through two points (x_1,y_1) and (x_2,y_2). When you learned linear functions, you learned a formula for the slope and it had a nice formulation as "rise over run." The formula for b is not so nice, but serviceable. There are a couple of ways to handle this. One is to transform to a linear equation using logarithms and using the formula for slope, and then transforming back. Another way is to solve a system of exponential equations. We will do the latter, since solving systems of exponential equations is generally useful on the FM exam.
Keep in mind that we know (x_1,y_1) and (x_2,y_2), but not a and b (and we do not care about a).

task.p: Divide the top equation by the bottom equation. Write the result. Why is this valuable strategically?

section.p: Given an accumulation function A(t), we would like to find the instantaneous percentage change at time t. Since exponential functions are characterized by constant percentage changes, this means we are interested in the base of the exponential function that best approximates A(t) at time t. In financial terms, this is the best approximation of A(t) using compound interest. Since we are dealing with instantaneous changes, we will assume our approximation involves continuous compounding. Hence we will denote our instantaneous percentage change by \delta_t and expect the base to our approximating exponential function to be e^{\delta_t} (can you see where this is going?).

statement.p: As with the derivative, we start by approximating the base using two points that are close: (t,A(t)) and (t+h,A(t+h)), where we think of h as "small". Find an equation for the base b_h of the exponential function passing between these points.

introduction.p: As with derivatives, we are interested in finding \lim_{h \rightarrow 0} b_h

task.p: Rewrite b_h as \mathrm{exp}\left(\ln(b_h)\right) and simplify as much as possible using laws of exponents. Why is this strategically useful?
Since the function e^x is continuous, \lim \mathrm{exp}(f(h)) = \mathrm{exp}(\lim f(h)). Use this fact to rewrite \displaystyle{\lim_{h \rightarrow 0}} b_h.
Finally, if you simplified \ln(b_h) appropriately, you should see a familiar type of limit in the exponent. Use that to finish up taking the limit, and explain how \delta_t fits into this.

statement.p: Explain what \delta_t means from a financial perspective.
